episodes.original_body:
Case: Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023
Client: Ashlee Williams

DOA: 8/29/23 (9pm)
MVA - P was turning L at a green light. Def coming from the opposite direction, ran a red light and t-boned P on the passenger side.
Happened in New Albany Indiana

New Albany PD responded but she has no info

Injuries: P had a seizure and required CPR at the scene. R arm, P claims she urinated on her self, R side ribs, DX with concussion, had abdominal bleeding. P was unconscious at the scene.
EMS to UofL 
Treating at Starlite 

Employment: UPS
Job Title: Package Handler 
Hourly Wage: 21$

Pip: Liberty Mutual 
No claim info

P vehicle: 2013 Kia Optima
Unsure location of vehicle now

Bi: unsure

Def Vehicle: unsure
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on August 29, 2023, with Ashlee Williams regarding a motor vehicle accident that occurred that evening in New Albany, Indiana. The date of the accident is August 29, 2023, at approximately 9:00 PM. The MVA involved P turning left at a green light when the defendant, coming from the opposite direction, ran a red light and t-boned P on the passenger side.

New Albany Police Department responded to the scene, but Ashlee Williams has no information from them. 

Injuries at the scene included a seizure requiring CPR. P sustained injuries to the right arm and right side ribs, and she claims she urinated on herself. She was diagnosed with a concussion and had abdominal bleeding and was unconscious at the scene.

EMS transported her to the University of Louisville (UofL); she was treated at Starlite. 

Employment: Ashlee Williams is employed by UPS as a Package Handler, with an hourly wage of $21. PIP coverage is Liberty Mutual, with no claim information available. P’s vehicle is a 2013 Kia Optima, and the current location of the vehicle is unknown. BI coverage is unknown. Defendant’s vehicle information is unknown.
episodes.author: Justin Chumbley

Case: Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023. Client: Ashlee Williams.

On September 14, 2023, Jessa Galosmo of the Whaley Law Firm forwarded an email thread (Fwd: 14-55R0-02D) originally sent by her to Aaron Whaley, Bryce Koon, and Justin Chumbley. The forwarded note concerns a motor vehicle collision that occurred on August 29, 2023 involving Dewayne Ward, Julmonzhae Moore, Daquan Graham, and Ashlee Williams, and indicates that Bodily Injury (BI) liability has been denied.

The forwarded chain includes a message from State Farm Claims (HOME CLMS-STATEFARMCLAIMS) dated September 14, 2023 at 11:33 AM, with the subject 14-55R0-02D and addressed to jessa@whaleylawfirm.com. The message asks recipients to open attachments for more claim information or next steps. It also contains a warning to avoid sending sensitive personal information via email (such as Social Security numbers, financial account numbers, driver’s license numbers, or health/medical information) and instructs that if such information must be sent to State Farm, the sender should request a secure email channel through their claim associate. The message includes reminders about not missing calls regarding the Auto and Homeowners claims, advising to text AUTO or HOME to 62789 to obtain a claim contact card or to download one on a mobile device.

The correspondence identifies Aaron Lovato as a State Farm Injury Claims Specialist and provides his contact number: (970) 395-4331. The email thread closes with best regards from Jessa Galosmo of the Whaley Law Firm, including her firm’s contact details: Ph: (502) 357-9975 and Fax: (502) 364-9363.

On September 1, 2023, Jessa Galosmo, using the Whaley Law Firm address jessa@whaleylawfirm.com, sent an email to Ashlee Williams at ashleewilliams1247@gmail.com, instructing her to complete and sign the Liberty Mutual documents and to return them once done. episodes.natural_language:
In the case Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023, involving client Ashlee Williams, on November 6, 2023, Jessa Galosmo of the Whaley Law Firm forwarded a State Farm denial letter to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon regarding four individuals: Dewayne Ward, Daquan Graham, Ashlee Williams, and Julmonzhae Moore.

The forwarded message originated as a State Farm email with the subject 14-55R0-02D, sent on Friday, November 3, 2023 at 6:45?PM from the address HOME CLMS-STATEFARMCLAIMS to jessa@whaleylawfirm.com. The body included the line "statefarm.com?" and instructed the recipient to open attachments for more claim information or next steps.

The message also contained a security reminder: for protection, do not include sensitive personal information such as Social Security numbers, credit or debit card numbers, driver’s license numbers, or health/medical information in an email. If such information must be transmitted to State Farm, the sender advised contacting the claim associate to request a secure email channel.

Additionally, the communication provided instructions for obtaining claim contact cards via text: text AUTO to 62789 for auto claims, or text HOME to 62789 for homeowners claims, with options to download the cards on a mobile device.

The message included the signature of Aaron Lovato, a State Farm Injury Claims Specialist. The forwarded email concluded with the Whaley Law Firm’s signature, “All the best, Jessa Galosmo,” along with the firm’s contact information: Ph: (502)357-9975 and Fax: (502)364-9363.

episodes.natural_language:
This case concerns Ashlee Williams and her motor vehicle accident (MVA) that occurred on August 29, 2023. The client is Ashlee Williams, and the file is labeled Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023.

On November 10, 2023, a forwarded email thread was circulated regarding Claim #054658453-01 for Ashlee Williams. The forwarding notice came from Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm and was sent to Aaron Whaley, Bryce Koon, and Justin Chumbley at Whaley Law Firm. The subject of the forwarded message was “FW: Claim#:054658453-01 / Ashlee Williams,” and it carried the body of an original email from Robert Elliott.

In Robert Elliott’s message, sent on Friday, November 10, 2023 (about 10:13 AM, though the time is shown as 10:13?AM), Elliott explains that each of the recipient firms represents a party making an injury claim arising from the August 29, 2023 auto accident. He informs them that their insured, Dewayne Ward, carries Bodily Injury liability limits of $25,000 per person / $50,000 per accident. Elliott requests that any and all medical bills and records be forwarded at their earliest convenience. He also asks for permission to review the receiving party’s PIP (Personal Injury Protection) file documents. He invites the recipients to contact him with any questions or concerns. The message is signed sincerely by Robert Elliott, with the contact number 317-805-2841.

Additional details included in the message metadata indicate the Claim-Number as 054658453, the Exposure-Number as 01, the Category as Manual Outbound E-Mail, the Description as undefined, and the Template-Id as BIFREEFORM. The note also identifies that the policy is underwritten by Liberty Mutual Personal Insurance Company, and it references Liberty Mutual’s address: 2023 Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, 175 Berkeley Street, Boston, MA 02116.

The forwarding email itself was sent by Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm to Aaron Whaley, Bryce Koon, and Justin Chumbley on Friday, November 10, 2023 at 10:34:22 AM -0500. The message includes Jessa’s signature line: “All the best, Jessa Galosmo, Whaley Law Firm, Ph: (502)357-9975, Fax: (502)364-9363,” and notes the Whaley Law Firm contact details.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023. Client: Ashlee Williams.

On December 11, 2023, Whaley Law Firm forwarded an email thread concerning Claim 054658453-01 for Ashlee Williams. The forwarded message began with an email from Jessa Galosmo to Justin Chumbley, dated December 11, 2023 at 3:20 PM. The body of the forwarded chain includes a message from Robert Elliott stating, “Hello, We were already in receipt of the letter of representation from your office. Please see the email below from 11/10/2023. Thank you,” followed by his guidance for faster claims processing and contact methods.

In Robert Elliott’s original message, sent November 10, 2023 at 10:14 AM, he explained that each of the firms involved represents a party making an injury claim arising from the August 29, 2023 auto accident. He advised that their insured, Dewayne Ward, carries Liability Bodily Injury limits of $25,000 per person and $50,000 per accident. He requested that all medical bills and records be forwarded at the earliest convenience and asked for consent to review the client’s Personal Injury Protection (PIP) file documents. Elliott invited any questions or concerns and provided his contact information: 317-805-2841.

The email thread contains additional notes and metadata indicating the following: Claim-Number 054658453, Exposure-Number 01, Category Manual Outbound E-Mail, Description undefined, Template-Id BIFREEFORM. The policy is underwritten by Liberty Mutual Personal Insurance Company, with the address listed as 175 Berkeley Street, Boston, MA 02116. Robert Elliott’s email also included standard notices about the firm’s communications preferences: for faster claims processing, correspondence should be sent by email, ShareFile, or other electronic means; all Liberty Mutual Claims Employees are currently working from home to protect themselves and others; and a prompt to review Liberty Mutual’s privacy policy at www.libertymutual.com/privacy. A footer from Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm appears, with her contact details: Ph: (502)357-9975 and Fax: (502)364-9363.

In sum, the forwarded exchange confirms representation for the Ashlee Williams claim arising from the 8/29/2023 MVA, references the insured Dewayne Ward with BI limits of $25,000/$50,000, requests the forwarding of all medical bills and records, and seeks permission to review the client’s PIP documents, along with ongoing communications and policy details tied to Liberty Mutual.

Case: Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023. Client: Ashlee Williams. The file documents communications with Liberty Mutual regarding a motor vehicle accident dated August 29, 2023, involving multiple claimants: Daquan Graham, Naomi Robinson, Ashlee Williams, and Julmonzhae Moore.

On January 11, 2024, Liberty Mutual sent an email to Jessa Galosmo at Whaley Law Firm as well as to counsel at other firms (scott@stoutheukelaw.com and lgraham@kpattorney.com) with the subject Claim#:054658453-01 / Daquan Graham, Naomi Robinson, Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore. In that message, Liberty Mutual stated that it had received bodily injury demands for Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore and that it appeared to have enough information to globally tender the available bodily injury policy limits of $25,000 per person and $50,000 per occurrence to the clients listed (Daquan Graham, Naomi Robinson, Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore). Liberty Mutual asked for the offices to reach an agreement on how the available limits would be divided among the four claimants, and it offered to appoint defense counsel and schedule a mediation if needed. The email was signed by Robert Elliott and included his contact number, 317-805-2841, and it was issued under a Liberty Mutual Personal Insurance Company policy (© 2024 Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, 175 Berkeley Street, Boston, MA 02116). The metadata associated with this message identified the Claim-Number as 054658453, Exposure-Number as 01, Category as Manual Outbound E-Mail, Description as undefined, and Template-Id as BIFREEFORM.

On January 23, 2024, at 11:33:40 AM, Jessa Galosmo forwarded the January 11 email to Atty. Whaley with a brief note requesting guidance: “Hi Atty. Whaley, How should I respond here?” The forwarded thread includes the earlier message from Robert Elliott and its content, along with the header “FW: Claim#:054658453-01 / Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore.”

In Elliott’s January 23, 2024 message (dated 9:39?AM), he reiterated that Liberty Mutual had not yet received a response to the January 11 communication and asked whether Whaley’s office had been in contact with the representatives for the other claimants involved in the 8/29/2023 auto accident. The message again referenced the claim number 054658453 and the exposure number 01, and it was addressed to Jessa Galosmo with the same contact context as before. The correspondence confirms that Liberty Mutual remained prepared to tender the policy limits and to coordinate through defense counsel or mediation if the parties agreed on a division of the limits among Daquan Graham, Naomi Robinson, Ashlee Williams, and Julmonzhae Moore. The document closes with the same policy disclosure from Liberty Mutual and the signature line for Jessa Galosmo of the Whaley Law Firm, including the firm’s phone and fax numbers.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023. Client: Ashlee Williams. This record summarizes email communications concerning Claim #054658453-01, involving Daquan Graham, Naomi Robinson, Ashlee Williams, and Julmonzhae Moore, with counsel from Whaley Law Firm and associated firms.

On January 23, 2024, at 11:10 AM, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm (Louisville, KY) sent an email to James Kamensky, Esq., and Scott Stout & Heukelaugh (with copies to others) regarding the Liberty Mutual settlement. In the message, Whaley stated that Liberty Mutual had tendered its policy limits of $50,000 to be divided among the four individuals, that he represents Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore, and that he proposed apportioning the settlement based on medical bills, asking whether any objections existed. The email included the standard attorney–client/work product privilege disclaimer.

Earlier, Lexi Graham, Case Manager for the involved firms, replied on January 23, 2024 at 11:16 AM. In her message, she informed Aaron that she had cc’d the handling attorney James Kamensky on the email and included her contact information and signature. Her note also contained the usual confidentiality notice.

James Kamensky, Esq. followed up later that day, January 23, 2024 at 12:08 PM. He wrote that they were currently gathering medical bills for Naomi Robinson but that, generally, they were comfortable with apportionment based on medical bills. He also indicated that he would advise once the medical bill information was available.

On January 31, 2024, at 12:34:47 PM, Aaron Whaley sent another message asking for the medical-bill amounts for each client. He requested that all parties forward the amounts they had. He listed two figures he already had: Ashlee Williams had medical bills totaling $35,454.24, and Julmonzhae Moore had medical bills totaling $29,092.40.

The communications show the parties coordinating on how to apportion a $50,000 settlement among the four claimants—Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, Daquan Graham, and Naomi Robinson—based on the medical bills, with ongoing efforts to gather the relevant billing information for all four clients and with standard confidentiality protections in place.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on February 19, 2024, with Sarena regarding Ashlee Williams, the client involved in the motor vehicle accident dated August 29, 2023 (Case: Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023).

The client is very frustrated and reports that she either does not receive callbacks or is told conflicting information repeatedly. After reviewing the file, it appears the client’s vehicle BI coverage (the client is a passenger in LiMu) has tendered policy limits. The at-fault vehicle (State Farm) is denying liability, but we are revisiting the liability decision with a witness statement. The client was advised that a Global Tender cannot be distributed until all damages are known. Per notes awaiting Dequan MBs. Dequan is incarcerated (3-4 years before release date) and has only had chiropractic treatment. The client was advised that AW will contact her to discuss Global Settlements in more detail.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023 involves Ashlee Williams following a motor vehicle accident on August 29, 2023, with Daquan Graham, Naomi Robinson, and Julmonzhae Moore also named in the claim. The matter is identified as Claim No. 054658453-01. The recited communications show ongoing settlement discussions among counsel from Whaley Law Firm and Stout & Heuke Law Office, with James Kamensky and Lexi Graham among the recipients and August 2023 accident-related claimants copied on the messages.

The core issue in the correspondence is how to allocate Liberty Mutual’s $50,000 liability limit among the four claimants. Liberty Mutual tendered the full $50,000 to be divided among Daquan Graham, Naomi Robinson, Ashlee Williams, and Julmonzhae Moore, and Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore were represented by Aaron Whaley. Whaley proposed apportioning the limits using the medical bills as the basis for division and asked whether there were any objections.

In the early exchanges, Whaley reported the following medical-bill amounts: Ashlee Williams had $35,454.24 in medical bills, and Julmonzhae Moore had $29,092.40. He also noted that those figures were being used to inform the proposed apportionment. Lexi Graham informed the group that the handling attorney James Kamensky was cc’d on the email thread. James Kamensky indicated that they were still gathering medical bills for Naomi Robinson and that apportionment based on medical bills would be the general approach, with further advisement to follow once the bills were in. On January 31, 2024, Whaley asked for the amounts of medical bills each client had, reporting that he already had Ashlee Williams at $35,454.24 and Julmonzhae Moore at $29,092.40.

Scott Stout of Stout & Heuke later stated on February 8, 2024 that they were gathering bills and records for Daquan Graham as well and did not object to dividing the settlement based on medical bills. A follow-up on February 12, 2024 confirmed that Daquan Graham’s medical bills were $7,195.00.

By March 1, 2024, Whaley followed up again, noting it was Friday and seeking confirmation that the remaining outstanding medical bills were only those for Naomi Robinson, with the implication that all other medical-bill totals were already identified in the apportionment plan.

In summary, the record shows a four-party claim under Liberty Mutual’s limits, with the proposed method of allocation anchored to medical-bill totals: Ashlee Williams $35,454.24, Julmonzhae Moore $29,092.40, Daquan Graham $7,195.00, and Naomi Robinson’s bills not yet finalized as of the last update. The parties have been coordinating through multiple emails from January through March 2024 to finalize the bill totals and confirm the apportionment method.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

Initial client contact on March 7, 2024, with Ashlee Williams regarding the Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023 case. Sarena received a call from the client after reviewing FG notes and advised Williams that there had been no movement since last week per a FG note from AW, and that AW is awaiting CoC MRs.

During the call, the client asked whether we could provide these records ourselves or what the process was. We advised that the CoC Esq has to provide the records, and that CoC is not our client. We also advised that medical providers do have a minimum of 30 days to respond to RR and 15 days for postal service. We noted that we cannot speak as to when the RR was sent since we do not work in the CoC office, but AW has been routinely checking in with CoC to push him along. Attempts have been unsuccessful to date, but AW is continuing to try. The client expressed understanding and appreciated the update.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023. Client: Ashlee Williams. Re: Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, Daquan Graham / Claim#: 054658453-01. The communications below involve the Whaley Law Firm and James Kamensky, Esq., on behalf of the clients, with multiple recipients and copies to related counsel and adjusters (Lexi Graham, Scott Stout, Robert Elliott) and the client Ashlee Williams. The subject matter centers on Naomi Robinson’s medical bills and records, the submission of bills for Daquan Graham, and the status of the distribution of the global policy limit tender.

On April 9, 2024, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm sent an email to James Kamensky, Esq., asking how things were progressing with the records and bills for Naomi Robinson. The message was copied to Lexi Graham, Scott Stout, Robert Elliott, and Ashlee Williams, and was dated Tuesday, April 9, 2024 at 2:25 PM Eastern Time.

Previously, on March 14, 2024 at approximately 11:38 AM, James Kamensky, Esq. replied that they were Waiting on medical bills and records to arrive for Naomi Robinson. This reply came with James Kamensky’s standard attorney contact information and firm signatures.

Also on March 14, 2024 at 10:01 AM, Lexi Graham, the Case Manager, sent a message stating that she had cc’d the handling attorney on the Naomi Robinson matter. Her message included confidentiality notices common to attorney–client communications and provided her office details across multiple locations in Missouri, Illinois, Louisiana, and Wisconsin, along with direct contact information.

Earlier still, on March 13, 2024 at 2:44 PM, Scott Stout, of Stout & Heuke Law Office, informed the group that Daquan Graham’s bills had been submitted (“Daquan Graham/Stout & Heuke had submitted our bills.”). His signature block included contact information for the Louisville, Kentucky and Downtown Louisville offices, with both phone and fax numbers.

Just prior to that, on March 13, 2024 at 2:41 PM, Aaron Whaley asked for updates, noting that they were waiting on Naomi Robinson to submit her medical bills.

On March 6, 2024 at 7:48 AM, Robert Elliott of Liberty Mutual asked for guidance on whether the offices had reached an agreement regarding the distribution of the global policy limit tender to the clients. The email thread included an image placeholder for missing images, and a reminder that the policy was underwritten by Liberty Mutual Personal Insurance Company. The metadata attached to this email identified the claim number 054658453, exposure number 01, and categorized it as a Manual Outbound E-Mail, with a template labeled BIFREEFORM. The Liberty Mutual correspondence was signed by Robert Elliott, who provided a phone number (317-805-2841) in his signature.

Throughout these exchanges, the communications were sent among the law firms and Liberty Mutual personnel involved in the Ashlee Williams motor-vehicle-accident matter (MVA) from August 29, 2023, with the overarching issues being Naomi Robinson’s medical bills and records, Daquan Graham’s submitted bills, and the distribution of the global policy limit tender. The email chain includes standard attorney–client and work-product confidentiality notices in each message.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023 involves Ashlee Williams and co-claimants Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, and Daquan Graham under Liberty Mutual Insurance, with claim number 054658453-01. The communications center on Naomi Robinson’s medical records and bills and on the distribution of the global policy limit tender. The parties in the email thread include Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm (Louisville, KY); James Kamensky, Esq., of KP Attorneys; Lexi Graham (Case Manager); Scott Stout of Stout & Heuke Law Office; and Robert Elliott of Liberty Mutual, with Ashlee Williams copied on the correspondence. The thread runs from March to April 2024 and references a policy under Liberty Mutual Personal Insurance Company, including a note in the March 14 email that the messages are confidential attorney–client and/or work product privileged material.

The first substantive item appears in a March 6, 2024 message from Robert Elliott at Liberty Mutual, asking for guidance on whether the offices had come to an agreement on the distribution of the global policy limit tender to the clients. A subsequent March 13, 2024 message from Aaron Whaley asks for updates on Naomi Robinson’s records and medical bills. Later that same day, Scott Stout replies that “Daquan Graham/Stout & Heuke had submitted our bills.” Aaron Whaley follows up again on March 13, 2024, noting that they are “just waiting on Naomi Robinson to submit her medical bills.” On March 14, 2024, Lexi Graham emails to inform that she has cc’d the handling attorney on the Naomi Robinson matter. In the same thread, James Kamensky, Esq., responds with a March 14, 2024 message stating, “Waiting on medical bills and records to arrive for Naomi Robinson.” This March 14 exchange includes the standard attorney–client and/or work product privileged notices in the signatures.

Throughout the thread, the claim remains the same, and the communications repeatedly center on Naomi Robinson’s required medical bills and records and the status of bills for Daquan Graham. The April 9, 2024 message from Aaron Whaley asks again, “James how are we doing on the records and bills for Naomi?” and a final follow-up on April 16, 2024 asks, “Following up again on the records and bills for Naomi Robinson. James, do you have these records and bills? If not what is the hold up?” The chain thus documents ongoing efforts to obtain Naomi Robinson’s medical documentation and to finalize the handling of bills and the distribution of the global policy limit tender in this multipart MVA case.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

Case: Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023. Client: Ashlee Williams. This matter concerns the motor vehicle accident on August 29, 2023, involving Ashlee Williams and co-claimants Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, and Daquan Graham, identified under Liberty Mutual claim number 054658453-01. The accompanying correspondence tracks efforts by counsel for the plaintiffs and the insurer to obtain Naomi Robinson’s medical records and bills, as well as other bills related to the case.

In early March 2024, Robert Elliott of Liberty Mutual asked whether the offices had reached an agreement on the distribution of the global policy limit tender to the clients. By March 6, 2024, the record indicates that the request for Naomi Robinson’s medical bills and records was still outstanding. On March 13, 2024, Aaron Whaley asked James Kamensky for updates on Naomi Robinson’s records and bills, asking what the hold‑up might be if the records were not yet available. Shortly thereafter, Scott Stout stated that Daquan Graham/Stout & Heuke had submitted their bills. On March 14, 2024, Lexi Graham informed the group that she had cc’d the handling attorney for Naomi Robinson, and later that day James Kamensky replied that they were waiting for Naomi Robinson’s medical bills and records to arrive.

The thread continued with a follow‑up on April 9, 2024, when Aaron Whaley again inquired about the status of Naomi Robinson’s records and bills. On April 16, 2024, Aaron followed up once more, asking James whether the records and bills had been obtained and, if not, what was causing the delay. James Kamensky responded on the same day that the request was still in process with UofL Hospital in Louisville, KY. A subsequent message from Aaron Whaley reiterated the inquiry about Naomi Robinson’s records and bills.

Finally, on May 7, 2024, Aaron Whaley wrote to James Kamensky again, noting concern and asking whether there were issues obtaining the records. He pointed out that it had been since February, at least, and sought an update on the status of the records and bills for Naomi Robinson as part of the Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, and Daquan Graham matter (Claim #054658453-01). Throughout these exchanges, the primary focus remained obtaining Naomi Robinson’s medical records and bills, as well as other related bills, to advance the case.

episodes.natural_language:
This case note concerns Ashlee Williams in the motor vehicle accident matter titled Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023, with client Ashlee Williams and related parties Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, and Daquan Graham. The formal claim number is 054658453-01. The communications below were exchanged among the firm’s attorney Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, James Kamensky (Kamensky & Patteson, LLP), and the supporting team, including Lexi Graham, Scott Stout, Robert Elliott, and Ashlee Williams, across March through May 2024.

On May 13, 2024, Aaron Whaley sent an email to James Kamensky, with copies to Lexi Graham, Scott Stout, Robert Elliott, and Ashlee Williams, simply noting that he was “circling back again” and asking how things were progressing on the matter.

Earlier that week, on May 7, 2024, Whaley followed up again with James Kamensky, asking whether there were any issues obtaining certain records, and flagging that it had been since February at the very least.

In mid-April 2024, on April 16, James Kamensky replied that the request for records and bills remained in process with University of Louisville (UofL) Hospital in Louisville, Kentucky.

Significantly, in March 2024 there were several exchanges regarding Naomi Robinson and other related bills and records. On March 14, 2024, Lexi Graham, serving as Case Manager, informed the recipients that she had CC’d the handling attorney on Naomi Robinson’s matter, signaling that internal coordination was being managed among the handling attorney, the case team, and the insurer.

Earlier, on March 13, 2024, Scott Stout advised that Daquan Graham/Stout & Heuke had submitted their bills for the matter. His message provided Louisville and Downtown Louisville office contact details for Stout & Heuke Law Office.

Also on March 13, 2024, at 2:41 PM, Aaron Whaley sent a reply to Robert Elliott (with copies to Scott Stout and Lexi Graham, and to Ashlee Williams) asking for updates and noting that they were likely waiting on Naomi Robinson to submit her medical bills.

Shortly thereafter, at 2:44 PM on March 13, 2024, Scott Stout responded, confirming that Daquan Graham/Stout & Heuke had submitted their bills.

Earlier still, on March 6, 2024, Robert Elliott from Liberty Mutual asked for guidance on whether the offices had reached an agreement regarding the distribution of the global policy limit tender to the clients. The thread at that time referenced the policy being underwritten by Liberty Mutual Personal Insurance Company and included the typical attorney–client and work-product confidentiality language found in the signatures of the emails. The messages also contained standard professional signatures with the respective offices’ addresses: Kamensky’s offices in Columbia, South Carolina, and Birmingham, Alabama; and Stout & Heuke’s offices in Louisville, Kentucky; as well as other locations listed in the signatures.

Throughout these communications, the key actors remained the same: Ashlee Williams and the related claimants, Aaron Whaley (Whaley Law Firm), James Kamensky (Kamensky & Patteson, LLP), Lexi Graham (Case Manager), Scott Stout (Stout & Heuke Law Office), and Robert Elliott (Liberty Mutual), with Ashlee Williams also copied on the emails. The underlying themes included obtainingMedical records and bills (notably for Naomi Robinson), the submission of bills by Daquan Graham (on behalf of Stout & Heuke), and efforts to resolve timing and fund distribution questions related to the global policy limit tender.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

In the case Ashlee Williams, a motor vehicle accident matter dated August 29, 2023, the client Ashlee Williams, along with Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, and Daquan Graham, is being handled under Claim number 054658453-01. The matter involved Whaley Law Firm and KP Attorneys, with Liberty Mutual as the insurer, and the correspondence stream included Aaron Whaley (Whaley Law Firm), James Kamensky (KP Attorneys), Lexi Graham (case manager), Scott Stout (Stout & Heuke), Robert Elliott (Liberty Mutual), and Ashlee Williams.

The communications begin with questions about the status of the University of Louisville (UofL) medical records. On June 4, 2024, Aaron Whaley sent an email to James Kamensky asking why it was taking six months to obtain the UofL records and offering assistance to help move things along so he could advise his clients.

Looking back through the thread, the first noted point in the chain appears in early March 2024 with Robert Elliott of Liberty Mutual asking whether the offices had reached an agreement on distributing the global policy limit tender to the clients, which was a separate point of coordination in the case.

On March 13, 2024, Scott Stout reported that Daquan Graham, via Stout & Heuke, had submitted their bills. That same day, Aaron Whaley followed up with James Kamensky, asking for updates and specifically whether Naomi Robinson had submitted her medical bills, noting that it had been at least since February and implying a delay or hold-up.

The following day, March 14, 2024, Lexi Graham notified the team that she had cc’d the handling attorney on the Naomi Robinson matter. Later that day, at about 11:38 a.m., James Kamensky stated that they were waiting on Naomi Robinson’s medical bills and records to arrive. The thread shows standard attorney-client and work-product confidentiality notices within the signatures, consistent with the firm practices.

Over the next weeks, additional follow-ups occurred. On March 13 and March 14, the group continued to seek updates on Naomi Robinson’s records and bills, with Aaron Whaley and others asking for status and James Kamensky noting that Naomi’s records and bills were still pending.

On April 9, 2024, Aaron Whaley again asked how the records and bills for Naomi were coming along. James Kamensky replied on April 16, 2024 that the request was still in process with UofL Hospital in Louisville, Kentucky. Aaron Whaley then followed up again on April 16, 2024, asking James whether he had Naomi Robinson’s records and bills, and, if not, what the hold-up might be.

As spring progressed, the follow-up continued. On May 7, 2024, Aaron Whaley asked if there were any issues obtaining the records, noting that it had been since February at least. The conversation persisted, and on May 13, 2024, Aaron circled back once more, asking how things were progressing. James Kamensky replied on May 13, 2024 that the requests were still in process. A separate response on May 13, 2024, at 2:11 p.m., again stated that the requests were still in process.

Throughout the thread, it is noted that Daquan Graham’s bills had been submitted, as Scott Stout had indicated, while Naomi Robinson’s medical records and bills remained the outstanding item to be obtained. The chain shows ongoing coordination among the law firms, Liberty Mutual, and the client team, with repeated inquiries about the Naomi Robinson records and bills and periodic confirmations that the records were still in process.

In summary, from March through June 2024, the team repeatedly sought Naomi Robinson’s medical bills and records, with Daquan Graham’s and the other bills already submitted, and the UofL hospital records for Naomi Robinson unresolved. By June 4, 2024, Aaron Whaley explicitly questioned the six-month delay in obtaining the UofL records and offered to assist to move the process forward so he could advise his clients.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023. The case concerns Ashlee Williams, with related references to Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, and Daquan Graham, under Claim number 054658453-01. The matter centers on obtaining medical records and bills, particularly from the University of Louisville (UofL) hospital in Louisville, Kentucky, for Naomi Robinson, as part of the ongoing representation by Whaley Law Firm and allied counsel.

On June 24, 2024 at 4:21 p.m. Eastern Time, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm—located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222 and reachable at 502-583-4022—sent an email asking, “Any progress on this?” The message was addressed to James Kamensky, Esq., and copied to Ashlee Williams and several other involved counsel and parties, including Robert Elliott of Liberty Mutual, Lexi Graham, and Scott Stout, among others. The email thread that followed reveals a multi-month effort to secure UofL records and the medical bills for Naomi Robinson.

The chronology begins earlier in 2024. On June 4, 2024, James Kamensky wrote to the team asking for a good point of contact (POC) for UofL so he could relay it to their records team. He signed with his firm’s multi-office address listing, and included the standard confidential/material-privilege notice typical of attorney-client communications.

Earlier, on May 13, 2024, Aaron Whaley sent a message asking, “Circling back again. James, how are we doing?” This followed a prior exchange in which James Kamensky had replied that “Requests are still in process.” In that same period, the parties continued to discuss the status of the records and bills.

The thread traces back to March 13–14, 2024. On March 13, 2024, at 2:41 p.m., Aaron Whaley asked James Kamensky for updates on the case, particularly regarding the records. At 2:44 p.m. that day, Scott Stout of Stout & Heuke Law Office responded that Daquan Graham/Stout & Heuke had submitted their bills. The next day, March 14, 2024, Lexi Graham, the case manager, informed the group that she had cc’d the handling attorney for Naomi Robinson. Later that day, at 11:38 a.m., James Kamensky replied that they were waiting on medical bills and records to arrive for Naomi Robinson.

That weekend and into April 2024, the status remained unsettled. On April 9, 2024, Aaron Whaley asked, “James how are we doing on the records and bills for Naomi?” On April 16, 2024, at 11:56 a.m., James Kamensky stated that the request was still in process with the UofL hospital in Louisville, KY. Earlier that same day, at 11:47 a.m., Aaron Whaley followed up again, asking whether James had the records and bills for Naomi Robinson and, if not, what was causing the hold-up.

By May, the delays were described more pointedly. On May 7, 2024, Aaron asked, “James, I am just following up on this. Are you having any issues getting these records? It has been since February, at least.” Then, on May 13, 2024, Aaron again pressed, “Circling back again. James, how are we doing?” James replied later that day, “Requests are still in process.” A few minutes earlier, on May 13, 2024, at 2:01 p.m., Aaron had written to James with the same query, and at 2:11 p.m., James reaffirmed that the requests were still in process.

In the midst of these exchanges, there was confirmation that Daquan Graham/Stout & Heuke had submitted our bills, as noted by Scott Stout in his March 13, 2024 message. This collaboration involved multiple parties: Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm; James Kamensky, Esq., for KPATT; Lexi Graham, the case manager; Scott Stout of Stout & Heuke Law Office; and Robert Elliott of Liberty Mutual, with Ashlee Williams cc’d on communications.

The thread includes the usual attorney-client and work-product confidentiality notices embedded in signatures, and lists a broad set of offices and contact details for the respective attorneys: James Kamensky’s multi-location offices (Columbia, SC; Birmingham, AL; Indianapolis, IN) and Boca Raton, FL; Aaron Whaley’s Louisville office; Lexi Graham’s assorted offices in Clayton, MO; Chicago, IL; New Orleans, LA; Milwaukee, WI; and Boca Raton, FL; Scott Stout’s Louisville offices; and Robert Elliott of Liberty Mutual.

In summary, from March through June 2024, counsel repeatedly sought, followed up, and attempted to obtain Naomi Robinson’s medical records and bills from the UofL hospital, with Daquan Graham/Stout & Heuke having submitted some bills, and with the handling attorney for Naomi Robinson identified. As of the June 24, 2024 email, there remained no final confirmation of receipt of all records and bills, and Aaron Whaley prompted another check for progress. The case remains linked to the motor vehicle accident for Ashlee Williams dated August 29, 2023, with related claim participants and the same Claim number: 054658453-01.

episodes.natural_language:
In the Ashlee Williams case, docketed as Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023 and involving clients Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, and Daquan Graham under Claim 054658453-01, the parties handled a sequence of records, bills, and policy-tender issues across several months in early 2024. The thread begins with Liberty Mutual’s Robert Elliott asking whether the offices had reached an agreement on the distribution of the global policy limit tender to the clients, a query dated March 6, 2024.

On March 13, 2024, Scott Stout of Stout & Heuke Law Office advised that Daquan Graham’s bills had been submitted. That same day, Aaron Whaley followed up, asking James Kamensky whether the records and bills for Naomi Robinson were in hand, and if not, what was causing the delay. The inquiry reflected the ongoing effort to obtain Naomi Robinson’s medical records and bills.

The next day, March 14, 2024, Lexi Graham, the case manager, informed the team that she had cc’d the handling attorney on the Naomi Robinson matter. Later that morning, James Kamensky replied that they were waiting on Naomi Robinson’s medical bills and records to arrive.

On April 9, 2024, Aaron Whaley again asked James Kamensky how they were progressing with Naomi Robinson’s records and bills. A week later, on April 16, 2024, Whaley followed up once more: “Following up again on the records and bills for Naomi Robinson. James, do you have these records and bills? If not what is the hold up?” Kamensky’s response two minutes later indicated that the request was still in process with the University of Louisville (UofL) hospital in Louisville, Kentucky.

Finally, on June 26, 2024, Aaron Whaley emailed James Kamensky and Ashlee Williams, asking for an update. He stated that if UL (UofL) had not yet provided the information, he would like Kamensky to disclose the amount of Naomi Robinson’s other bills to help him form a clearer picture.

Throughout these exchanges, the communications carried their typical attorney–client confidentiality notices, with multiple emails noting privileged material and the confidential nature of the communications. The overarching issue centered on Naomi Robinson’s medical bills and records, the submission status of Daquan Graham’s bills, and the distribution of the global policy limit tender among the involved clients in Claim 054658453-01, with the University of Louisville hospital in Louisville, KY identified as the current hold-up for Naomi Robinson’s records.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023. This matter concerns Ashlee Williams and her co-claimants—Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, and Daquan Graham—under Claim Number 054658453-01, arising from a motor vehicle accident on August 29, 2023. The case file shows an ongoing effort to obtain medical records and related bills from the University of Louisville (UofL), with a focus on Naomi Robinson’s records and the bills submitted by Daquan Graham. The latest communication, dated July 10, 2024, comes from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm to James Kamensky, with copies to Lexi Graham, Scott Stout, Robert Elliott, and Ashlee Williams. The message asks for updates on the UL (UofL) records, noting that it has been over five months since limits were tendered.

The thread traces a multi-month effort to obtain records from UofL. On June 4, 2024, James Kamensky asked for a good point of contact for UofL so he could relay the request to their records team. In a follow-up the same day, Aaron Whaley asked whether there was a reason it was taking six months to obtain UofL records and offered to assist, emphasizing the need to inform his clients. Earlier in the month, on May 13, 2024, Kamensky replied that the requests were still in process, and Whaley circulated a further follow-up the same day, asking for an update. A prior message from May 7, 2024, had already questioned whether there were issues getting the records since February. The chain also shows that on April 16, 2024, Kamensky stated the request was still in process with UofL Hospital in Louisville, KY, and Whaley followed up about Naomi Robinson’s records and bills. In mid-March 2024, Lexi Graham cc’d the handling attorney for Naomi Robinson, and Scott Stout reported that Daquan Graham/Stout & Heuke had submitted our bills. Earlier that day, Aaron Whaley asked Robert Elliott for any updates, noting that they were waiting on Naomi Robinson to submit her medical bills. The earlier portion of the thread includes standard attorney signatures and confidentiality notices in the email footers, and shows that the involved parties included Ashlee Williams, with communications circulated among James Kamensky, Lexi Graham, Scott Stout, and Robert Elliott, among others.

As of the July 10, 2024 email, the status remains unresolved with UofL regarding the records, and Naomi Robinson’s medical bills have not had a final submission confirmed, while Daquan Graham’s bills had been reported as submitted by Scott Stout. The thread reflects ongoing efforts to obtain a point of contact at UofL, to secure the necessary records and bills, and to update the clients on progress.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023. Client: Ashlee Williams. Re: Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, Daquan Graham / Claim#: 054658453-01. The matter involves multiple clients—Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, and Daquan Graham—under claim number 054658453-01, with communications among Ashlee Williams’s counsel and related parties about obtaining medical records and bills from the University of Louisville (UofL) and related billing submissions.

On July 12, 2024 at 13:53:51 -0400, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm sent an email to James Kamensky, Esq., with copies to Lexi Graham, Scott Stout, Robert Elliott, and Ashlee Williams. The subject reiterated the four clients and the claim number, and the body stated simply: Circling back on this. Would like to get this resolved as soon as possible. This email was a follow-up in a longer thread about UL records and related bills.

The prior thread began with a message on July 10, 2024, in which Aaron Whaley asked: Any updates on the UL records? It has been over 5 months since limits were tendered. Before that, on June 4, 2024 at 4:45 PM, James Kamensky, Esq. asked: Do you have a good point of contact for UofL? I will relay to our records team. James’s signature block shows him as a Partner with offices in Columbia, SC; Birmingham, AL; and Indianapolis, IN, and he includes the standard privileged material disclaimer.

Earlier that same day, June 4, 2024 at 4:26 PM, Aaron Whaley replied to James Kamensky with copies to Lexi Graham, Scott Stout, Robert Elliott, and Ashlee Williams. He asked whether there was a reason it was taking six months to obtain UofL records and offered assistance to advise his clients.

The preceding messages show a longer back-and-forth. On May 13, 2024 at 2:11 PM, James Kamensky replied: Requests are still in process. That followed a May 13, 2024 2:01 PM message from Aaron Whaley circling back again and asking how things were progressing. In early May 2024, Aaron had been following up after a February timeframe, noting ongoing issues obtaining the records.

On April 16, 2024, James Kamensky informed that the request was still in process with UofL hospital in Louisville, KY. Earlier that morning, Aaron Whaley had written (April 16, 2024 11:47 AM) asking whether James had the records and bills for Naomi Robinson and, if not, what was causing the hold-up. James’s prior reply on April 16, 2024 at 11:56 AM stated the same: the request remained in process with the UofL hospital.

The thread also includes communications related to Naomi Robinson’s records and bills. On March 14, 2024, Lexi Graham, Case Manager, replying to Scott Stout and Aaron Whaley, indicated that she had cc’d the handling attorney for Naomi Robinson. In a separate March 13, 2024 message, Scott Stout of Stout & Heuke Law Office reported that Daquan Graham’s bills had been submitted. The body of that exchange includes the Louisville offices and contact details for Stout & Heuke, as well as the standard attorney–client privileged notice.

Throughout these exchanges, the participants consistently referenced Naomi Robinson’s medical records and bills, the status of the records request with UofL hospital in Louisville, KY, and the need to obtain or confirm the bills associated with Naomi Robinson and the other named clients. By mid-July 2024, despite multiple follow-ups and the assignment of a point of contact for UofL, the UL records and related bills for Naomi Robinson reportedly remained outstanding, and the team reiterated that they wished to resolve the issue as soon as possible for the four clients under the same claim.

In sum, this case’s documentation reflects ongoing efforts since at least February 2024 to obtain Naomi Robinson’s medical records and bills (and related submissions for Daquan Graham) from UofL, with repeated requests, several follow-ups across multiple weeks and months, and no definitive resolution as of the July 12, 2024 correspondence. The matter is part of the Ashlee Williams case (MVA dated 08-29-2023) involving Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, and Daquan Graham under Claim# 054658453-01, with communication among Aaron Whaley, James Kamensky, Lexi Graham, Scott Stout, Robert Elliott, and the clients.

This narrative consolidates the Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023 case notes and the accompanying email correspondence, including the proposed allocation of medical-bill recovery and the ongoing communications about medical records and related issues.

Case overview and proposed allocation
The case is titled Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023 and involves client Ashlee Williams. The correspondence concerns four claimants: Naomi Robinson, Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, and Daquan Graham, under Claim #: 054658453-01. The initial note documents a correspondence dated Monday, July 15, 2024 at 12:59:43 PM (-0400) from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm (agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com) to James Kamensky, Esq. (jkamensky@kpattorney.com), with cc’s to Lexi Graham, Scott Stout, Robert Elliott, and Ashlee Williams (ashleewilliamsmvaz3887726@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). The subject line is “Re: Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, Daquan Graham / Claim#:054658453-01.”

A proposed breakdown based on total medical bills is as follows:
- Naomi Robinson: $15,383.44
- Ashlee Williams: $16,503.23
- Julmonzhae Moore: $14,734.08
- Daquan Graham: $3,379.25

The accompanying calculations are listed as:
- Naomi Robinson 32754 0.307668781 15383.43905
- Ashlee Williams 35138.24 0.3300647087 16503.23543
- Julmonzhae Moore 31371.4 0.2946815777 14734.07889
- Daquan Graham 7195 0.06758493251 3379.246626

Ongoing discussion about hospital records, bills, and coverage
In a reply dated Friday, July 12, 2024, at approximately 2:05 PM (the time is recorded as 2:05?PM in the record), James Kamensky, Esq. wrote that hospital records and billing were pending. He noted that collateral source information showed a total billed amount of $26,554 plus $6,200 at a rehab clinic. He asked for input on several topics: what about the other claimants’ specials, whether the injuries were significant, and whether applicable UIM (uninsured/underinsured motorist) coverage applied.

James Kamensky’s signature and contact details follow in the record, including multiple office locations (Columbia, SC; Birmingham, AL; Indianapolis, IN) and mailing address in Boca Raton, FL, with the usual attorney–client and/or work product privileged material disclaimer.

Earlier and related correspondence in the thread
The thread includes a substantial history of back-and-forth between Aaron Whaley and James Kamensky (and occasionally others such as Lexi Graham, Scott Stout, and Robert Elliott), spanning several months in 2024. The following timeline captures the gist of those communications, preserving the dates and the key points:

- July 12, 2024 (1:54 PM): Aaron Whaley wrote to James Kamensky, cc’ing Lexi Graham; Scott Stout; Robert Elliott; and Ashlee Williams, circulating on the topic of the Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, Daquan Graham case and asking to advance resolution.

- July 12, 2024 (2:05 PM): James Kamensky’s earlier message (quoted above) regarding hospital records, billing, collateral sources, total billed amounts, and questions about specials, injury significance, and UIM.

- July 10, 2024 (11:53 AM): Aaron Whaley asked for updates on UofL records, noting that it had been over five months since limits were tendered.

- June 4, 2024 (4:45 PM): James Kamensky asked for a good point of contact (POC) for UofL, indicating intent to relay to the records team. The record shows a parallel exchange on the same day from Aaron Whaley (4:26 PM) raising the question of the status of UofL records and offering assistance if needed, followed by James’s request for a UofL POC.

- June 4, 2024 (4:26 PM): Aaron Whaley responded, asking whether there was a good POC for UofL and noting the desire to know why it had taken six months to obtain UofL records, offering to assist in advising clients.

- May 13, 2024 (2:11 PM): James Kamensky replied that the requests were still in process.

- May 13, 2024 (2:01 PM): Aaron Whaley circled back again, asking how the status was progressing.

- May 7, 2024 (1:10 PM): Aaron Whaley followed up, asking whether there were issues obtaining records, noting it had been at least since February.

- April 16, 2024 (11:56 AM): James Kamensky stated that the request was still in process with the UofL hospital in Louisville, KY.

- April 16, 2024 (11:47 AM): Aaron Whaley followed up on the Naomi Robinson records and bills, asking James if he had them or what was causing the delay.

- April 9, 2024 (2:25 PM): Aaron Whaley asked James how things were progressing with the records and bills for Naomi.

- March 14, 2024 (11:38 AM): James Kamensky indicated that they were waiting on medical bills and records to arrive for Naomi Robinson.

- March 14, 2024 (10:01 AM): Lexi Graham sent an entry with the subject line “RE: Ashlee W” to Scott Stout, Aaron Whaley, and Robert Elliott, with James Kamensky cc’d, though the snippet ends with an incomplete subject line.

Privileged material and contact details
Throughout the thread, standard attorney–client and work product privileged material notices appear in the signatures. James Kamensky’s signature appears with multiple office locations (Columbia, SC; Birmingham, AL; Indianapolis, IN) and a Boca Raton mailing address, including the disclaimers about confidentiality and the proper handling of messages if the recipient is not the intended recipient.

In sum
The note captures a case in which four claimants—Naomi Robinson, Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, and Daquan Graham—are being managed together under Claim #: 054658453-01, with an initial proposed allocation based on total medical bills and accompanying calculations. It also documents a multi-month effort to obtain hospital records and bills (notably from UofL) and to confirm collateral sources, specials for the other claimants, injury significance, and applicability of UIM coverage. The email thread shows ongoing coordination between the law firms and the insurer regarding these records, bills, and related issues, including multiple reminders and requests for points of contact at UofL, with several professional disclaimers about confidentiality woven throughout.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023. Client: Ashlee Williams. Re: Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, Daquan Graham / Claim#: 054658453-01.

The matter and related communications concerned four claimants—Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, and Daquan Graham—under the above claim number. The email thread began in mid-July 2024, with Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm and James Kamensky, Esq., coordinating colleagues and sending copies to Ashlee Williams and others, including Robert Elliott of Liberty Mutual, Lexi Graham, and Scott Stout of Stout & Heuke Law Office, among others. The thread includes several law-firm office location blocks for James Kamensky, Esq., detailing multiple regional addresses and contact information.

On July 17, 2024, Aaron Whaley asserted that the parties did not have access to any underinsured coverage either. Earlier that day, James Kamensky indicated that, with respect to underinsured coverage, Naomi Robinson did not have it (stating “Underinsured? Naomi does not, see attached.”) and he provided a standard attorney-client confidentiality footer in the email chain.

A separate message in the chain from Scott Stout, dated July 15, 2024 at 1:24 PM, acknowledged a misreading and apologized, instructing recipients to disregard that previous portion of his communication. In the same exchange, Stout’s contact information for Stout & Heuke Law Office was included, along with Louisville and downtown Louisville office addresses.

Earlier in the thread, on July 12, 2024 at 2:05 PM, James Kamensky asked for hospital records and noted collateral-source information showing total billed amounts of $26,554 plus $6,200 at a rehab clinic. He queried about the status of specials for the other claimants, whether there was a significant injury, and whether applicable UIM would apply. Aaron Whaley had previously indicated in the thread that he was awaiting these records and information to facilitate resolution.

A day earlier, on July 10, 2024 at 11:53 AM, Aaron Whaley had prompted for updates on University of Louisville (UofL) records, noting that it had been over five months since limits were tendered, and he offered assistance. May and June 2024 exchanges show ongoing efforts to obtain POCs and to keep requests in process; James Kamensky advised that requests were still in process and, later, sought a good point of contact for UofL records to relay to their records team. The conversation throughout May and June 2024 repeatedly referenced delays in obtaining UofL records.

On July 12, 2024 at 1:54 PM, Aaron Whaley circled back, expressing a desire to resolve the matter promptly. That message was part of the longer chain noting hospital and collateral-source information, and continued with follow-up messages on July 15 and July 17.

In terms of the proposed allocation of amounts based on total medical bills, James Kamensky provided a breakdown on July 15, 2024. He itemized proposed shares as follows:
- Naomi Robinson: $15,383.44 (billed amount listed as 32,754 with a proportion of 0.307668781, producing 15,383.43905)
- Ashlee Williams: $16,503.23 (billed amount listed as 35,138.24 with a proportion of 0.3300647087, producing 16,503.23543)
- Julmonzhae Moore: $14,734.08 (billed amount listed as 31,371.4 with a proportion of 0.2946815777, producing 14,734.07889)
- Daquan Graham: $3,379.25 (billed amount listed as 7,195 with a proportion of 0.06758493251, producing 3,379.246626)

The total figures presented by Kamensky reflected a breakdown based on the total medical bills among the four claimants, with the calculated shares aligning to the numbers above.

Throughout the thread, standard confidentiality language appeared, including the declaration: “ATTORNEY–CLIENT AND/OR WORK PRODUCT PRIVILEGED MATERIAL. This email message and any attachments are confidential. If you are not the intended recipient, please immediately reply to the sender and delete the message from your email system.” Various office locations and contact information for the involved attorneys were included in the circulating emails.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023. Client: Ashlee Williams. This note summarizes the email communications concerning the four claimants in the matter titled “Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, Daquan Graham / Claim#: 054658453-01,” dated August 1, 2024.

On August 1, 2024, Aaron Whaley of the Whaley Law Firm emailed James Kamensky, Esq., with copies to Ashlee Williams, Robert Elliott, Lexi Graham, Scott Stout, and others. In that message, Aaron stated that he had authority to resolve Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore, and he asked whether James Kamensky had authority to resolve Daquan Graham and Naomi Robinson. The message closed with thanks.

The prior thread began on July 17, 2024. In James Kamensky’s reply at approximately 12:10 PM, he wrote that he needed a few days to confer with the client and assess medical billing, but he would let the sender know. In an earlier message on the same day, around 12:09 PM, Aaron Whaley responded that they did not have access to any underinsured coverage either. Earlier still that day, at about 10:55 AM, James Kamensky had asked, “Underinsured? Naomi does not, see attached.” This exchange indicates questions about underinsured motorist coverage for Naomi Robinson.

Prior to that, on July 15, 2024 at 1:24 PM, Scott Stout sent a message (to Aaron Whaley and James Kamensky, with Lexi Graham, Robert Elliott, and Ashlee Williams cc’d) noting, “Wait. I misread that. I see where I made the mistake. My apologies. Please disregard.” This was part of a back-and-forth effort to confirm the correct allocations and coverage among the claimants.

Earlier on July 15, 2024 at 1:00 PM, Aaron Whaley replied to James Kamensky (with copies to Lexi Graham, Scott Stout, Robert Elliott, and Ashlee Williams) with a proposed breakdown based on total medical bills. The proposed allocations were as follows: Naomi Robinson: $15,383.44; Ashlee Williams: $16,503.23; Julmonzhae Moore: $14,734.08; Daquan Graham: $3,379.25. Whaley included the corresponding mathematical breakdown below these figures, listing for Naomi Robinson the values 32754, 0.307668781, and 15383.43905; for Ashlee Williams 35138.24, 0.3300647087, and 16503.23543; for Julmonzhae Moore 31371.4, 0.2946815777, and 14734.07889; and for Daquan Graham 7195, 0.06758493251, and 3379.246626.

On July 12, 2024 at about 2:05 PM, James Kamensky sent a message noting that hospital records and billing were pending, but that collateral source information had been received showing a total billed amount of $26,554 plus $6,200 at a rehab clinic. He asked what had happened with the other claimants’ specials, whether there were any significant injuries, and whether underinsured motorist coverage (UIM) might apply.

That same day, July 12, 2024 at 1:54 PM, Aaron Whaley replied, “Circling back on this. Would like to get this resolved as soon as possible.” He was reiterating the push to finalize the matter promptly.

On July 10, 2024 at 11:53 AM, Aaron Whaley asked, “Any updates on the UL records? It has been over 5 months since limits were tendered.” He was seeking progress on obtaining underinsured/uninsured motorist records from the University of Louisville (UofL).

Earlier still, on June 4, 2024, at 4:45 PM, James Kamensky asked, “Do you have a good POC for UofL? I will relay to our records team,” seeking a point of contact at UofL to obtain records.

Finally, on June 4, 2024 at 4:26 PM, Aaron Whaley responded to James Kamensky, saying, “James, still waiting? Is there a reason why it is taking 6 months to get UofL records? Happy to help. I am just trying to get a little bit o[?].” The email appears cut off at the end of that line.

Throughout these exchanges, the participants included Ashlee Williams (the client), Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, and Daquan Graham as claimants, with the primary attorneys Aaron Whaley, James Kamensky, Esq., Scott Stout, and Robert Elliott (Liberty Mutual) among the correspondents. The communications address medical billing, coverage issues including underinsured motorist coverage, collateral sources, and the status of medical bills and hospital records. The case file reference remains 054658453-01, associated with the case Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Ashlee Williams was involved in a motor vehicle accident on August 29, 2023. The client listed is Ashlee Williams, and the matter covers four claimants: Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, and Daquan Graham, under Claim Number 054658453-01.

The communications span several weeks in mid-2024 and involve Ashlee Williams’s case file shared among multiple counsel and parties. The thread opens with Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm noting that James Kamensky represents Naomi Robinson and confirming that all counsel had been contacted. He asks to be informed when authorization is obtained and inquires of Scott Stout whether he has discussed authorization with Daquan Graham. James Kamensky replies that his firm “only rep[s] Robinson and auth pending,” signaling that authority to resolve the other claimants was not yet established. The exchange includes standard attorney-client and work-product privilege notices.

Earlier in the chain, on July 17, 2024, James Kamensky indicates he will need a few days to confer with his client and assess medical billing before providing a determination. In parallel, Aaron Whaley notes that his firm “has authority to resolve Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore,” and asks whether the other two claimants, Daquan Graham and Naomi Robinson, have authority to resolve as well. At that point, there is also a statement that the party does not have access to any underinsured coverage.

Complicating the discussions are questions about uninsured or underinsured motorist issues and collateral sources. On July 12, 2024, James Kamensky asks for hospital records and billing to be completed, and notes collateral source information showing total billed amounts of $26,554 plus $6,200 at a rehab clinic. He also asks about “other claimants’ specials,” whether any of the claimants sustained significant injury, and whether applicable UIM coverage exists. Earlier on July 12, Aaron Whaley responds, circling back and expressing a desire to resolve the matter promptly.

On July 15, 2024, James Kamensky provides a proposed distribution breakdown based on total medical bills. The proposed figures are Naomi Robinson: $15,383.44; Ashlee Williams: $16,503.23; Julmonzhae Moore: $14,734.08; Daquan Graham: $3,379.25. He also presents a calculation showing totals such as Naomi Robinson: $32,754; a proportion of 0.307668781 yielding $15,383.43905; Ashlee Williams: $35,138.24; a proportion of 0.3300647087 yielding $16,503.23543; Julmonzhae Moore: $31,371.40; a proportion of 0.2946815777 yielding $14,734.07889; Daquan Graham: $7,195; a proportion of 0.06758493251 yielding $3,379.246626. Scott Stout later responds that he misread the situation and asks that the prior distribution be disregarded.

As the weeks progressed, further questions about underinsured coverage were addressed. On July 17, 2024, James Kamensky asks whether Naomi Robinson has underinsured coverage, noting “Underinsured? Naomi does not, see attached.” The following day, Aaron Whaley replies that his side does not have access to any underinsured coverage either, and James indicates again that more time is needed to confer with the client and review medical billing.

On August 1, 2024, the thread clarifies the scope of representation: James Kamensky states, “We only rep Robinson and auth pending.” Earlier that day, Aaron Whaley asks whether Kamensky’s office has authority to resolve Daquan Graham and Naomi Robinson, noting that he has authority to resolve Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore and seeking confirmation regarding the other two claimants. The emails also include standard privilege notices.

Finally, on August 2, 2024, Aaron Whaley writes that he knows James Kamensky rep Robinson and that he has emailed all counsel. He asks to be informed when authorization is obtained and asks Scott Stout whether he has had a chance to discuss authorization with Daquan. The chain ends with renewed emphasis on obtaining authorization and coordinating across all four claimants under Claim #: 054658453-01.

Throughout the exchange, the parties reference university records and insurer communications, including the University of Louisville records (UL records) and POC considerations for UofL, with June 4, 2024, as an earlier touchpoint about providing a point of contact for UL records. The thread contains multiple firm signatures, addresses, and privilege notices, illustrating ongoing efforts to resolve authorization status and determine the allocation of any potential settlement among the four claimants.

The case file is titled Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023, with client Ashlee Williams. The matter concerns four claimants listed in the subject line: Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, and Daquan Graham, associated with Claim number 054658453-01.

The first item in the recorded chain occurs on August 6, 2024, when Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm emailed James Kamensky, Esq., and Ashlee Williams to check whether James had discussed the case with his client and obtained approval for a global settlement. The email asked for confirmation that a global settlement had been approved.

A prior reply surfaced from August 1, 2024, in which James Kamensky stated that his firm “only rep Robinson” and that authorization was pending. Later that same day, Aaron Whaley sent a message to James asking for clarity on authorization: he stated that he had authority to resolve Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore and asked whether James had authority to resolve Daquan Graham and Naomi Robinson.

The exchange continued in mid-July 2024. On July 17, 2024 at 12:10 PM, James Kamensky replied in the chain that he would need a few days to confer with his client and to assess medical billing before providing a final answer. Earlier that day, at 12:09 PM, Aaron Whaley responded that he did not have access to any underinsured coverage either. Also on July 17, Aaron’s message reflected that Naomi Robinson’s underinsured coverage had been addressed in the thread, with James noting that Naomi does not have underinsured coverage and asking to see attached information.

On July 15, 2024, a phone-style thread included a proposed breakdown based on total medical bills. Aaron provided the following figures for the four claimants:
- Naomi Robinson: $15,383.44
- Ashlee Williams: $16,503.23
- Julmonzhae Moore: $14,734.08
- Daquan Graham: $3,379.25

Accompanying the proposed numbers were a simple proportional breakdown using total billed amounts: Naomi Robinson with a billed amount of 32,754 (ratio 0.307668781) yielding 15,383.43905; Ashlee Williams with 35,138.24 (ratio 0.3300647087) yielding 16,503.23543; Julmonzhae Moore with 31,371.4 (ratio 0.2946815777) yielding 14,734.07889; and Daquan Graham with 7,195 (ratio 0.06758493251) yielding 3,379.246626. The exchange appears to have been an attempt to structure a settlement based on medical bill totals.

Earlier, on July 12, 2024, Aaron had indicated that hospital records and billing were pending, but collateral source information showed total billed amounts of $26,554 plus $6,200 at a rehab clinic. He also asked about other claimants’ specials, whether there was a significant injury, and what applicable underinsured motorist (UIM) coverage might apply. James had replied on the same day that collateral-source information was being reviewed and that hospital records and billing were pending, and he inquired about UL records and UIM considerations.

On July 10, 2024, Aaron had asked for updates on UL records, noting that more than five months had passed since limits were tendered. Earlier, on June 4, 2024, James had asked whether there was a good point of contact for University of Louisville (UofL) records so he could relay the information to his firm’s records team.

Throughout the thread, standard attorney-client and work-product privilege notices appeared in each email, indicating that the messages and any attachments were confidential and intended only for the named recipients. The communications also listed multiple recipients beyond the principal participants, including Robert Elliott, Lexi Graham, Scott Stout, and the Louisville Williams client, among others, and each message carried the accompanying confidentiality notice.

By August 1, 2024, the communications showed a narrowing of authority. James stated that his firm only represented Naomi Robinson and that authorization was pending. In the same week, Aaron confirmed that he had authority to resolve Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore and asked whether James had authority to resolve Daquan Graham and Naomi Robinson.

Finally, on August 6, 2024, Aaron Whaley followed up with James Kamensky, asking whether James had had a chance to discuss the matter with his client and obtain approval for the global settlement. The message concluded with thanks.

In summary, the records reflect an ongoing effort between the Whaley Law Firm and James Kamensky, Esq., to determine authority to resolve individual claimants and to pursue a global settlement among four parties in Claim 054658453-01. The discussions spanned June through August 2024, covering issues of authority to settle, underinsured coverage, hospital billing and collateral sources, the status of UL records, and a proposed distribution of settlement funds based on total medical bills (with explicit dollar amounts for each claimant). The chain also includes notes about the status of the coverage, with Naomi Robinson not having underinsured coverage, and a recurring focus on obtaining client approvals for any global resolution.

Case: Ashlee-Williams-MVA-08-29-2023. The client is Ashlee Williams, and the matter labeled for the file is Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, and Daquan Graham, Claim Number 054658453-01.

The correspondence in question centers on settlement discussions for the four claimants related to the motor vehicle accident. The chain begins with communications among Ashlee Williams’s counsel and related counsel as they assess representation and authority to resolve the matter.

On July 12, 2024, James Kamensky, Esq., sent a message noting that hospital records and billing were still pending. He reported that collateral source information had been received showing total billed amounts of $26,554, plus $6,200 at a rehabilitation clinic. He asked for input on the other claimants’ specials, whether any of the injuries were significant, and whether applicable underinsured motorist coverage (UIM) existed. The message included the heading for hospital and billing issues and referenced the four claimants.

Later on July 12, 2024, in a following thread, James asked about the status of underinsured coverage for the claimants, indicating that Naomi Robinson did not have underinsured coverage, and he referenced an attachment. This was followed by further exchanges through July 15 and July 17 addressing authority to resolve different claimants and the status of insurance coverage.

On July 15, 2024 at 1:00 PM, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm provided a proposed breakdown based on total medical bills for the four claimants:
- Naomi Robinson: $15,383.44
- Ashlee Williams: $16,503.23
- Julmonzhae Moore: $14,734.08
- Daquan Graham: $3,379.25

He included supporting figures in a line-item format showing the underlying numbers used to compute these totals (Naomi Robinson with a total of 32,754 and a factor of 0.307668781 producing 15,383.43905; Ashlee Williams with 35,138.24 and a factor of 0.3300647087 producing 16,503.23543; Julmonzhae Moore with 31,371.4 and a factor of 0.2946815777 producing 14,734.07889; Daquan Graham with 7,195 and a factor of 0.06758493251 producing 3,379.246626).

At 1:24 PM on July 15, 2024, Scott Stout (Stout & Heuke Law Office) replied: “Wait. I misread that. I see where I made the mistake. My apologies. Please disregard.” This indicated a correction to the prior proposed figures or assumptions.

Earlier that same day, at 10:55 AM, James Kamensky had asked whether Naomi Robinson’s claim involved underinsured coverage and requested the attached documentation, indicating that Naomi might not have underinsured coverage and seeking confirmation on that point.

On July 17, 2024 at 12:09 PM, Aaron Whaley responded: “We do not have access to any under insured coverage either.” At 12:10 PM, James Kamensky replied that he needed a few days to confer with his client and assess medical billing, but would let the other side know his position.

Also on July 17, 2024 at 12:10 PM, a prior message from James Kamensky indicated that they did not yet have complete authorization to resolve all four claimants, and that only Naomi Robinson was being represented with authorized settlement discussions pending for the others.

On August 1, 2024 at 1:41 PM, James Kamensky sent a message stating: “We only rep Robinson and auth pending.” In a subsequent email, also on August 1, 2024 at 1:40 PM, Aaron Whaley asked: “I have authority to resolve Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore. Do you have authority to resolve Daquan Graham and Naomi Robinson?” This exchange clarified that the sender had authority to settle Ashlee Williams and Julmonzhae Moore, while Kamensky indicated authority was still pending for Daquan Graham and Naomi Robinson.

Finally, on August 6, 2024, Aaron Whaley sent a message to James Kamensky (copied to Ashlee Williams) asking whether Kamensky had a chance to discuss the matter with his client and obtain approval for a global settlement. James Kamensky replied shortly after that the matter was “Still pending response.” Ashlee Williams replied, acknowledging the update and adding that her clients were pressing to get this matter resolved.

Additional context appears in the signature blocks and contact details included in the chain. James Kamensky’s firm lists multiple offices and addresses: 1320 Main Street, Ste 300, Columbia, SC 29201; 2100 Southbridge Parkway, Ste 650, Birmingham, AL 35209; 8888 Keystone Crossing, Suite 1300, Indianapolis, IN 46240; mailing address 925 S. Federal Hwy, 6th Floor, Boca Raton, FL 33432; and a general telephone number of 800-586-5555. The messages are marked as attorney–client and/or work-product privileged, with standard confidentiality notices.

In summary, the case involves four claimants under claim number 054658453-01 (Ashlee Williams, Julmonzhae Moore, Naomi Robinson, Daquan Graham) related to the MVA on August 29, 2023. The parties have been negotiating a global settlement, with representation and settlement authority for Naomi Robinson confirmed as partially in place and with authority still pending for Ashlee Williams’s co-claimants. The discussion has included assessments of medical bills, collateral sources, and potential UIM considerations, and the latest communications in early August 2024 indicate that the clients’ approval for a global settlement has not yet been obtained.
